Answers.MP Summary: arbitrary TCP and UDP connections and listens
Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Connect to a certain port (you can then write to this port)
Top-3 Similar Questions: ul_214471: How to create a TCP listener?
so_54321431: How can I loop until IP:port is not responding
Top-3 Scripts:
so_54321431: #!/bin/bash
for i in `seq 1 10`;
do
        nc -z -w 1 google.com 80 &> /dev/null
        if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
            echo OK
        else
            echo FAIL
        fi
done

Explanations about Options.-l:
Listen for an incoming connection rather than initiating a connection to a remote
 host. The destination and port to listen on can be specified either as non-optional
 arguments, or with options -s and -p respectively. Cannot be used together with -x
 or -z. Additionally, any timeouts specified with the -w option are ignored.
Explanations about Options.-w:
Connections which cannot be established or are idle timeout after timeout seconds.
 The -w flag has no effect on the -l option, i.e. nc will listen forever for a
 connection, with or without the -w flag. The default is no timeout.
Explanations about Options.-z:
Only scan for listening daemons, without sending any data to them. Cannot be used
 together with -l.

Explanations about Options.-l: Show only listening sockets. (These are omitted by default.)
Explanations about Options.-s: Display summary statistics for each protocol.
Explanations about Options.-n: Show numerical addresses instead of trying to determine symbolic host, port or user names.
